title: Bytes & Bites - Software Management Plans
text:
Theme: Software Management Plans and how you can benefit from them
Guest speaker: Dr.¬†Carlos Martinez-Ortiz Community Manager at the Netherlands eScience Center.
Register
This session of Bytes & Bites will focus on Software Management Plans (SMPs) and how your software project can benefit from planning ahead. SMPs are relevant for beginners and professionals alike and can be applied to any project of any size in any language. We will learn together how to create a SMP and discover in a playful way what components matter to our project.
Pizza will be served as always!

title: Bytes & Bites - National Advent of Code Challenge
text:
Theme: Advent of Code
Register
Psssst - we‚Äôre developing something nice for you. Details will follow as soon as we

title: Bytes & Bites - Bugs and Demos
text:
Theme: Bring your own bugs!
Register
This edition of Bytes and Bites is all about you and your code! Tell us more about what you are working on or share what is blocking you. We meet one last time before the summer break for an informal bug-party.

No preparation required
This meeting is as informal as you like. We make sure that there will be enough time and space to talk about what we are working on and what bugs us.


Have a bigger problem or would like to present your project with more time?
You can send us your projects or questions before if you want. This way we can plan presenter time or make sure that we have the right persons to answer your question as good as anyone can.

title: Bytes & Bites - Documentation and Good Practices
Bytes & Bites - Version Control
text:
Theme: Version Control
Register
Join us for the next engaging session of Bytes & Bites where will talk about being in control of your coding, jumping back to better times, and collaborating with others on a programming challenge. We will use Git and train with GitHub as an example platform.
You do not need to bring your own dataset for the practical part. Instead, we will challenge you with a TidyTuesday dataset about the most important thing for a researcher: Coffee We can be creative, work together in teams and have some tasty pizza and snacks.
‚≠êüëï Best analysis/visualization of the coffee dataset gets a cool shirt as a prize! üëï‚≠ê



Let us know what you want!
Fill in this short survey to shape B&B to your liking!

title: Bytes & Bites - Computational Analysis of Communication with Wouter van Atteveldt
text:
Theme: Computational Analysis of Communication
In this edition of Bytes & Bites, Prof.¬†Wouter van Atteveldt and Prof.¬†Damian Trilling will present their work at the Societal Analytics Lab and talk about their book ‚ÄúComputational Analysis of Communication‚Äù. The book gives a practical introduction to the analysis of texts, networks, and images with code examples in Python and R. The book is open and freely available, which makes computational techniques accessible (and fun!) to as many students and researchers as possible, regardless of means and institutional support.
Our guest speakers also well known for their journal: CCR - Computational Communication Research, an Open Access and community-owned journalabout the understanding, development and application of computational methods in communication research.
Register
Slides

title: Bytes & Bites - R Packaging
text:
Theme: R Packaging
Bytes & Bites is back! This time with a new host, the UBVU Research Software Engineer Charlie Greene, who will be taking over organising sessions from here on out.
Guest speaker: Dr.¬†Bj√∏rn Bartholdy Data Steward at TU Delft and general R wizard.
Register
This session of Bytes & Bites covers the topic of Reusability in software development and how using an R package over a project can increase it. We will cover how to make a package in R with an example project. Suitable for all levels!
Pizza will be served as always!

title: The Portal Project data
text:
import pandas as pd


d = pd.read_csv('data/portal_project.tsv', delimiter='\t')


Create separate tables

species = d.copy()[['species_id', 'species', 'genus', 'taxa']]
species = species.drop_duplicates()

species1 = d.copy()[['species_id', 'species', 'genus', 'taxa']].drop_duplicates()

observations = d.copy().drop(columns=['species', 'genus', 'taxa'])



Average hindfoot length per species

average_length = observations.hindfoot_length.mean(skipna=True)  # skipna=True is also the default


average_length

average_length_ps = observations.groupby('species_id', as_index=False).\
    agg(mean_hf_length = ('hindfoot_length', 'mean')).\
    merge(species, how='inner')
average_length_ps.head()

ratios = observations.\
    groupby(['species_id', 'year', 'sex'], as_index=False).\
    agg(nr = ('record_id', 'count')).\
    pivot(index = ['species_id', 'year'], columns = 'sex', values = 'nr')
ratios['mfratio'] = ratios.M / ratios.F
ratios = ratios.reset_index()

Number of observations per species and year

obspspy = observations.\
    groupby(['species_id', 'year'], as_index=False).\
    agg(obs = ('record_id', 'count'))

obspspy['totobs'] = obspspy.groupby('species_id').obs.transform('sum')

obspspy = obspspy[obspspy.totobs > 300].\
    merge(species, how='inner')

obspspy['speciesname'] = obspspy.genus + ' ' + obspspy.species

Make a plot

import plotnine as p9


(
    p9.ggplot(obspspy, mapping=p9.aes(x='year', y='obs', color='speciesname')) 
    + p9.geom_line()
)









(
    p9.ggplot(obspspy, mapping=p9.aes(x='year', y='obs')) 
    + p9.geom_line() 
    + p9.facet_wrap('speciesname') 
    + p9.scale_y_log10()
)

title: B&B notes 14-02-2025
text:
Present: Tijmen, Tycho, Stephanie, Brett, Sophie, Meron
Agenda: Discuss how to continue Bytes&Bites after departure Stephanie and Meron


Observation
Most time in planning B&B is preparing the program.
Many suggestions made:

less often meet-ups
schedule further in advance
no pizza to make registration less needed and organization easier
Brett, Tijmen, Kostas and Sophie are not able to invest time in organizing program.
Tycho can facilitate snacks, location and inviting people to come to the meeting. But can not create a research software related program.
Idea to combine Data Conversations with B&B somehow
Idea to have a low-effort coding cafe where people only go to code and see like-minded people ‚Äì> this was discarded as some more incentive is needed for people to come.
Idea to send a short survey around (e.g.¬†is pizza important for you? what is the main use of B&B for you?)
Shorter B&B (e.g.¬†16:00 - 17:00) or different time (e.g.¬†at lunch)




Two scenarios on how to continue, based on availability of organizers:

Put B&B on hold until new UB RSE+community manager are hired
Have a B&B walk-in hour with ITvO in the lead

title: Bytes & Bites - Data Visualisation Coding Tutorial
text:
Theme: A Data Visualisation Coding Tutorial in R and Python.
Programming beginners in R ans/or Python will be empowered to harness basic data analysis tools essential for Neuroscientific research and beyond. We will provide basic practical insights and hands-on experience to enhance your research analysis capabilities. Don‚Äôt miss this opportunity to enhance your skill set and network with fellow enthusiasts.
If you are a novice and wouldn‚Äôt want to miss some tasty pizza and snacks, this event is for you. We look forward to seeing you on Tuesday the 18th of June!
This session‚Äôs speakers are Fatima Khan and Carmen Dom√≠nguez, 2nd year Master in Neuroscience VU students. They created a visualization tutorial that can be done here.
Register Slides

Featured TidyTuesday Dataset
Would you like to practice your coding skills and experiment with others (or individually) with a real dataset that is (probably) not related to your research project? We select a featured dataset from the TidyTuesday Data Science Learning challenge that you can analyze during the event. Ask for help if you get stuck and practice your data analysis skills.
Talking about Pizza, how often do you wonder about science around cheese?

This week‚Äôs dataset is all about cheese: Dataset of the week

The data this week comes from cheese.com.
Cheese is nutritious food made mostly from the milk of cows but also other mammals, including sheep, goats, buffalo, reindeer, camels and yaks. Around 4000 years ago people have started to breed animals and process their milk. That‚Äôs when the cheese was born. Explore this site to find out about different kinds of cheese from all around the world.
248 cheeses have listed fat content.

Is there a relationship between fat content and cheese type?
What about texture, flavor, or aroma?

title: Bytes & Bites - EESSI
text:
Theme: Environment for Scientific Software Installations
In the first edition of 2024 of Bytes and Bites, Peter Stol (BAZIS, clusters and supercomputers) will tell you all about EESSI.
This event had to be cancelled due to unforeseeable circumstances! We will hear about EESSI later this year.

title: Bytes & Bites - Project Templates & AUMC Intro
text:
Theme: Templates & Introductions
Guest speakers: Dr.¬†Bauke van der Velde Reseach Data Management and Software Management Consultant at the AUMC, a recent start with a lot of programming experience within research (as the title would suggest). Dr.¬†Thomas Pronk a Research Software Consultant at the AUMC who has a focus on FAIR and open science, with a focus on improving research code quality.
Register
This week is a somewhat more open session. Starting with two presentations, the introduction of the AUMC Reseach Support team and the introduction of software project templates here at the VU. There will be plenty of space for questions and discussion after each presentation, as well as a general discussion session in the second hour.
Pizza will be served as always!

title: Bytes & Bites - Roundtable & Introduction
text:
Theme: Roundtable and Introduction to Bytes & Bites
Register
Slides (Introducing Bytes & Bites)
Our first session after the summer break will focus on our projects we‚Äôve been working on over the summer, and introduce our plans for the rest of the year. This can be software project related, but it‚Äôs also a great opportunity to talk about future plans for our software community meetings ‚ÄúBytes & Bites‚Äù. We used the summer break to identify interesting topics and sketch out some ideas for the remaining year. Let‚Äôs share some pizzas and discuss together some ideas.
We can collect our ideas in this Google Doc

title: Bytes & Bites - (how to) Bring your code
text:
Theme: (how to) Bring your code
This session will focus on your project! There will be time to work on your code, collaborate and ask for help.
We will talk about code reviews, what they are and how you could use them.
There will also be time to talk about future plans for our software community meetings ‚ÄúBytes & Bites‚Äù.
Let‚Äôs share some pizzas and discuss together some ideas.
There will also be time to ask questions related to programming, improve your programming skills, meet other researchers, or delve into any topic that piques your interest.
Register
Slides
 POSTPONED:
 In this edition of Bytes & Bites, Peter Stol (BAZIS, cluster computing and supercomputers) will tell you all about the European Environment for Scientific Software Installations (EESSI pronounced as ‚Äúeasy‚Äù).
 The EESSI is a brand new collaboration between different European HPC sites & industry partners, with the common goal to set up a shared repository of scientific software installations that can be used on a variety of systems, regardless of which flavor/version of Linux distribution or processor architecture is used, or whether it‚Äôs a full size HPC cluster, a cloud environment or a personal workstation.
